title: How has your life been since 2003? - Quora

response.answer_text: Oh let’s see, 2003, hmmmmm. 14 years ago. We had moved into our large new home back in 2000, and just recently had finished the second floor. In Mexico, many people do not get loans to purchase a home, you get someone to build it according to your own design and pay as you go. In these times, my career with Avery Dennison was in full swing, our daughters had been all in Elementary School with my wife attending her school cafeteria business. Times were great. we were awash in cash (any business more lucrative would require to go Breaking Bad,) Times in Ciudad Juarez back then were very tranquil and the overall economy was doing great. Back then, I just had turned 40 (2002) and my wife was 36. We two late-bloomers were at our shiny best, physically. Day and specially at night. In retrospect, these low 2000-years had been our most productive and happy years. In 2004, I had to readjust my career and would stop doing these frequent, extensive business trips of 2 to 3 weeks at a time. There was also that awful little row we got ourselves into, because my wife was dead certain that I was having an affair. The overall good life would keep going until the fall of 2007. Then all hell broke loose. The Juarez Drug War would start, and what that meant for us you can read here on Quora: Dieter Neth's answer to At what moment in your life did you witness true evil? We are no quitters and tried to stick it out. 4 years long. But we got the sense that we were sacrifying the life of our daughters over our ambition to not be quitters and to keep our beloved home. So by 2011, we were moving out. Back to Switzerland. This was a huge setback money-wise. As counterintuitive as this may sound, but we were barely able to take enough funds with us to restart our life over here - renting, not owning anymore! All five of us were busy trying to adapt to the new surroundings, learning the language (my wife and daughters) and get a new job (me). As of now, my daughters have fixed their jobs for now. Times are still tough. Due to my age and long absence, I could not go back into my original well-paid field (chemistry) and had to accept menial work. My wife has some recurring health issues and can only work sporadically. We are 55 and 50 years old now, our daughters are adults all three. This by itself has a different feel to it, when comparing to being younger. We are barely being able to stay above the poverty line. But things are not bad. Instead of lavish overseas trips, we explore the nearby areas. My wife is still delighted at the exuberance of flowers and vegetation, the abundant rain and that there are rivers, lakes and creeks everywhere (Juarez sits at the edge of a large sandy desert) Together we check out the sights of Switzerland I have largely missed out on myself when being younger, as I was spending my vacations abroad - mostly in the North Amercian Desert. So there is a lot of differences and very little stayed the same. We are still married. That has not changed. We still love each other. It also feels a bit different, it is becoming clear that our long, hot, passionate Mexican Summer has passed, making room for fall to encroach. But at least in Switzerland, fall is a delightful season!

2003 was without a doubt the worst year of my life. Don't want to post personal details here, let's just say we experienced a very difficult and traumatic family crisis, one that caught us totally by surprise and completely changed the nature and composition of our household. We basically had to rebuild our lives from the bottom up, and our family after 2003 was very different from before. So we pretty much could only move up from there, even with the occasional sideways. Some notable events since: The death of my father in 2006. Taken way too soon, IMHO.The loss of our home in 2007 due to foreclosure, from mismanaging the finances (largely my fault).The death of my beloved grandmother in 2007, at 93 years old. She had held it together for quite some time, but pretty much lost most of her faculties the last few months of her life. Her passing was not unexpected, but I really miss having her in our lives.Watching our middle daughter spiral downward into a life of drugs, something it took almost five years for her to get out of.Taking a layoff from a job I had done for the previous 14 years and was completely burned out on, with severance. The job relocated to where my commute was easily going to be at least 90 minutes one way, and that with ideal traffic (on the other side of metro Atlanta, GA). Badly timed with the economy falling off the cliff and it was almost two years before I was gainfully employed in a full time job again.The unexpected arrival of a week-old baby boy in 2009 almost literally on our doorstep (once again, withholding details). Who we eventually adopted and I am proud to say is a healthy and happy almost-8 year old kid today. Makes all the trials worth it.Having to relocate out of state for employment, with the expectation that the rest of the household would follow in a matter of weeks. Long story short, lost job after 90 days and had to scramble for alternate employment. Rest of family not able to follow for almost 16 months.After family finally came out, got another job which I've currently held for over six years.Had 4 grandchildren, starting in 2008 (boy), 2010 (girl), 2011 (boy), 2016 (girl). Don’t see them as much as I’d like.Decided to go back to school for accounting degree in 2015, taking online classes. As of right now, I'm one year away from the degree.Took epic road trip to California with family in 2016, revisiting the place where I lived 15 years of my life from my early teens and reunited with some very good friends after an absence of almost 20 years.I've put on way too much weight, and am starting to feel the effects from it. Really need to cut down, but have an addiction to good food.So, overall? Pretty good, after the debacle of 2003. Could be better, could be far worse. Things average out, the good mostly seems to overcome the bad and sometimes exceed it.

Let's see, in 2003 I was 12/13. I hit puberty and got fat.I started high school, was horribly bullied, got an eating disorder, got fatter.2004- Tried to commit suicide twice.2005- Mom started doing drugs.2006- Pinned my dad against a wall while he was in a rage, prevented him from killing my mom's thieving, druggie friend. I think I had a nervous breakdown, was never diagnosed though, purely speculation upon looking back.Early 2007- Left home. Lived on my own for a year and a half.2007- lost a lot of weight, was almost fit. Officially became Atheist.Late 2008- got hit by a drunk driver. Dislocated right shoulder and hip, right knee also badly damaged. Doctor can't believe no bones were broken. Discovered I have much higher than normal bone density, my addiction to milk finally explained.2009- can no longer work full time due to injuries. Parents contacted, mom has cleaned up. I move back home.Got fat again.2010- fail to finish high school. Move to Calgary with then boyfriend.2011–2013- nothing of major note. Ups and downs of life, finally broke a bone (ankle). Had a crappy job, went through 6 months of especially bad depression, got into art therapy. Therapy put me in contact with best job ever.Early 2014- pregnant!2014- pregnancy is evil.Late 2014- move closer to my parents in preparation to have baby. Best little girl ever officially starts her life on December 18th, 2014.2015- breasts malfunctioning, not making any milk. Highly emotional. Ex starts badgering me to let them sleep around with other people because I don't provide enough sex. To my eternal self hatred- I give in.Late 2015- Ex comes out as transgender. I begin the grieving process. It's not pretty. Trying to hold self together. Trying to be good mom and spouse.2016- separate from ex. Separation helps me realize how much we're not going to work. Alternating between being on good terms and bad terms with ex. Sometimes she's the asshole, sometimes I am. 2015 and 2016 pretty much worst years of life thus far. Living in parent's basement. Gramma dies April 14, 2016.Somewhere in 2015–16 I finally learned how to drive. Acquired a car of my very own, a 2006 Pontiac Torrent. Her name is Torry and I love her. She can be a piece of junk, but she's my piece of junk.2017 so far- still fat. Working on changing that. Tried to commit suicide via overdose, was caught before I took anything, now back in therapy.Panicking because almost done college course, do not feel ready to be back in the work force. Going to try anyway.Discovered marijuana earlier this year. Life improving. It actually helps my anxiety and depression without the bad side effects other medications were giving me.Still living in parent's basement.There you go, an overview of the last 14 years of my life. It's been pretty fucked up. May my future be a little less fucked up.

That was taken on 10 December 2002, but close enough. Since that date, I’ve moved five times, changed jobs four times, been in two long-term relationships, picked up a lot of gray hairs, and grown a beard because I hate my chin. I turned 30 years old a few months after this picture was taken. At the time, I was working as editor of three weekly newspapers (that was my office), and taking care of my parents, both of whom were ill at the time. In September of 2003, I was run over on a football field in Durham and suffered damage to four disks in by lower back, which have given me trouble off and on ever since, and more trouble than before in the last few months. In spite of that, I’m probably healthier at 44 than I was when I was 30, because I had some issues that I didn’t become aware of until a year or two later. I’ve made some decisions professionally that I wish I could reconsider in the 14 years since then, and there is one thing personally that I wish I could go back and advise someone to do something different than what I told them that day. In some ways, my life was a lot simpler then, and I just didn’t realize it.

Right, I was only 3 years old, damn. These are a few things that have changed in my life since then: My brother was born in 2005, I started primary school, we moved around many times as dad was in the military.In 2007 I cut my hair short, and little did I know it would take 10 years of bad haircuts for me to grow it out again.In 2008 we moved to Italy.In 2010 I started an Italian middle school in Naples.In 2012 my parents separated and my mother faced depression.Dyed my hair a natural red in 2013, a bright red in 2014 and 2015, pink in the summer of 2015 and purple/pink that September.In 2014 I started High school. This is the first time I have been in one school for more than two and a half years.I've been to Poland three times to visit my dad's girlfriend and new family.I've started smoking pot from 2015 to 2017 heavily, and now have reduced it as I'm trying to clear my lungs and not spend all my money.I'm in a stable relationship for almost a year now.Mum is better, has a boyfriend.My brother is huge, slightly annoying but sensitive and sweet. He has the same difficulty as I do in making friends.Read a ton of books since 2003, not just Freda the frog.And in two weeks I'm going to London for a month as a scholarship. I guess these changes are a lot as I've grown A LOT. Teenage years are meant for change.

So much can happen in 14 years. It's truly mind-boggling. But I'll give it a go. 2003 I was strung out on heroin, living part time with my boyfriend and part time in an abandoned house (because it was closer to the drugs). I was barely holding down my job as a flight attendant for a major airline. Getting high in the lav at 30,000 feet. I was copping dope in foreign countries and am amazed I lived through it. Since that time, the husband I had divorced me and remarried immediately. i watched my little sister get clean in May of 2004, so in Nov of 2004, I went to detox for what I hope to be, the last time. I quit my job when I got out, left the boyfriend and cut all ties with using buddies. I dedicated my life to getting and staying clean. The first gift I got was holding my first grandchild right after she was born. I was 10 months clean. 24 days later, I went on a date with the man I would end up marrying in 2009. I moved to his town to live with him in 2005. Through him I got a stepdaughter and 2 amazing grandsons. We traveled, had fun, went to meetings and were active in our grandchildrens lives. In 2011, I re-injured my neck, daredeviling on a tube behind a boat. My parents got a divorce (where they called me as a witness) and it was nasty. And on May 30, 2011 my father-in law died after a long illness and it started to feel like we couldn't catch a break. But 2012 would be better, right?? Feb 4 of 2012, my sisters only child, a girl of 26, drove her car in front of a tractor trailer, locked eyes with the driver and hit the brakes. The end result was gruesome, horrifying and lots of other adjective. My family came together like never before. We supported my sister financially and physically at times. We thought we had been through the worst possible thing. We were wrong. On May 19, 2012, after 6 months clean, my son (also an only child) decided to get high one more time and he died of a heroin overdose. This ripped my family to shreds. October 2012, the owner of the gym I managed, let me know she was shutting the doors and moving on. I was out of a job. I purchased as much of her equipment I could afford and Nov 2012, I opened my own space in a wing of my house. I take only the clients that feed my soul. 2013 brought my granddaughter and her mom to live 4 doors down and truly be in my life on the daily. 2014 we became legal foster parents to a 16 year old boy who put us through it but we loved him and offered to adopt. His mom met the benchmarks set by CPS and the day school was out June 2016, he was packed and ready to go. A month later he found his mother on the floor, unresponsive, with a needle sticking out of her leg. He was instrumental in getting her help and with the use of Narcan, the first responders saved her life. She is now in recovery but he was sent to a boy's home where he will probably age out of in Jan 2018. 2015 brought what may be our last grandchild. He is the light of our lives and he is here all the time. In Nov 2016, I opened the first female recovery house in our county. It's been a blessing and a curse but it gives me purpose. So, to recap, I lost a husband and found another. I lost two jobs and opened my own. I lost one niece and one son and got 3 grandchildren. I lost one town and got another. I found my family and then lost them again. I lost my reason to live and found lots of others. I lived through addiction, loss, physical pain and heartbreak. I also lived through joy and love and friendship and the intimacy of a true marriage. In Nov 2017, I will have 13 years clean and not all of them were easy but none of them were a reason to use.

There were any changes and improvement after some time since that year. In 2003, I had finished school but not in the best of manner, as the grades were not too good. I had planned to become a dentist, so I opted Pre-Medical in the college. I did well than before and decided to go for my career. I did become eligible by clearing the test to get enrolled in a certain college for BDS, but unfortunately I could not pursue my career. I felt dejected and was affected adversely as I did not have a Plan B in mind at that time. Anyways, reluctantly, I pursed BA where I had majors in International Relations, English Advanced and Islamic Studies. But after this, again I was unsure of my future. I chose to do MBA in HR and this was online. But this worked for me differently. During the first semester only, my creative or better side began to surface. I had written a small rough draft for an animation film in English and wanted to pursue it after MBA. Soon, I had plenty of ideas for writing and all. My mind had broadened and opened up seriously. I was more inclined towards creativity and was feeling better too. So, i just tried to get over MBA which ended well. This was nearly 7 years ago. I went into freelance writing and side by side I was getting inspired and motivated towards writing and creativity. I had also written a rough draft for a historical novel as well. In two years, I had formed my future plan that involved mostly writing and a development of a film. Now, this year finally, I have begun writing en English novel. It is fiction and is inspired by the real tragic incident of MH370 plane that got vanished 3 years ago. I intend to complete it later this year. So, I can say that my experiences have been good. i have changed a lot and improved a lot. I have become ambitious, passionate and boulder. I tried to be me and only follow or do what my heart and mind says to be. The only thing that I have with me all those years is simplicity and some innocence. This I think is necessary and will remain true for me indeed.

I was a toddler back in 2003, and a toddler who had no clue what he would have to go through in the future. She was born to parents the year before still grieving over the loss of their first child. Growing up, she knew she was different from the rest of the girls, but didn’t know how. Overall, elementary school was great, and arguably the best time of her life. Then middle school came. The hormones came in, and with that meant more freedom on the internet. She then came across the term transgender and after reading stories and watching videos, she realized- she was not a she, she was a he. From then on, the rest of middle school and early high school, did not go well. Anxiety, depression, parents not understanding, people at school being ignorant, and a Quora addiction causing grades to slip. He knew he could do better, but his computer was not helping. But, he needed his computer if he wanted to accomplish my homework. That’s where he - me - is now. A hormonal teenager dealing with a lot of mental problems, and all I can blame it on is my parents being slow to help me out and Quora.

That was the year I graduated from high school. I was 17 years young. It was a beautiful age in which I dreamt of being the next Alexander Hamilton. It was also a very stressful time. I was still learning English. I’d been in the country for only 2 years. It’s true that I was somehow let into AP English, but my conversational English was still not great.I was a deist. I had this conception of the divine as a figure that transcended any one religion. Different people around the globe were seeing the many faces of God through their imperfect lenses. Everyone was a bit right. Everyone was a bit wrong. Arguing was senseless.I was an undocumented immigrant. I had good grades in high school and I’d done pretty well on the SAT (1310/1600). That could have gotten me a scholarship somewhere. But was ineligible. I was neither a citizen, nor a permanent resident, nor a foreign student (I had no student visa). My status was “pending,” as my case for political asylum was making its way through the courts. I had to go to a community college. There, my counselor found me some scholarship assistance to attend my local university. In time, I would be granted asylum. But for years until that time, I had to battle the sense that all my hard work might be futile. What’s the point of working hard if they might deport me anyway?I was not great with girls. I started community college after having had only one girlfriend in high school. I was awkward, both insecure and conceited. My idea of courtship consisted in sending people I was interested in grandiloquent emails and dismissing them as not intelligent enough for me when they inevitably failed to respond in kind. I was very much afflicted with nice guy syndrome.I was not yet a liberal. I was willing to give Bush the benefit of the doubt on the Iraq War. Maybe he was just willing to sacrifice his reputation for the greater good of removing Saddam from office. How commendable! The tax cuts were controversial, but I don’t remember being particularly enraged. I thought blocking federal funding of stem cell research was silly, but I was very much opposed to abortion: why do women think they have the right to murder their children? I also thought the idea of gay marriage absolutely hilarious. These gays, they want to get married now? How amusing!I have changed in all these respects: My English is now, much to my chagrin, better than my French. It’s the language I would choose, if I were to write a book someday.I have become a̶n̶ ̶a̶t̶h̶e̶i̶s̶t̶ the Prophet of Horus.I am a citizen and a physician.At age 21, a girl was kind enough to tame me. I have been a more desirable partner ever since.I am now a solid liberal.

In 2003, I was a broken person, undergoing emotional and other forms of abuse at school. I actively wished to die every single day. I still remember waking up every morning and cursing the gods for letting me live. I had no friends, but one, who lived outside of Boston and he wasn’t able to be there for me. I prayed every night to let me die in my sleep. I had tried suicide once already, and Heather Dale’s music had convinced me keep going, but barely. I was all alone. I got out of bed out of pure spite. I had already been physically abused by my ex boyfriend. My mother was ill, and I was basically trying to survive till I was 18 and I could get the hell away from everyone. I honestly was a terrorist sympathizer and I dreamed of dying in a blaze of glory, in the service of a higher goal. Now, I am so far removed from that world. I have multiple advanced degrees. I’ve lived abroad. I’ve made true friends. I’ve come to peace with my sexual identity. I’ve seen my mother get well. My life began to have peace. It’s not perfect. I still have a lot of issues. I still struggle in so many ways, I have so many dreams I have yet to see, and obstacles I need to overcome. But compared to 2003, my life is paradise.

I was in a high school in a small village in Nepal. Now, I am writing this answer from New York. Differences: I had watched just 2–3 pornographic movies by 2003. By this age, I have watched many more and I am no longer a virgin.I thought I could be what I wish, be a rich and successful man just by studying hard (I used to wake up at at 4 am and study). Now, I do not have any formula for that.I wanted to be a physician and I am a pharmacist.I thought I would be a monk someday in future. Now, I don’t think the same.I used to look after cows and buffaloes. Now, I don’t.I used to eat meat rarely (Not more than 3 times a year). Now, I eat at least twice a week.I wanted to be a role model in the community. Help the needy. Cure the diseased one. Bring smile in the faces of the poor. Now, I wake up, eat breakfast, browse internet, walk, eat and sleep and I repeat it.I was an underweight and looked like a frail and sick teen. I have a right weight now.I used to dream of traveling. Now, I do it.I thought socialism is the solution for all the world problems. Now, I don’t think so.I used to write poems. I don’t do it now.I wished 50 hours make a day so that I would have more time to study my textbooks. 24 hrs a day is fine.Similarities: I still have positive attitute towards life and people. I still think I can at make a positive impact in my immediate surrounding. I am still an atheist. I still like reading books on science. I am still a shy and reserved person.

All of you kids answering this with “I was a newborn” are making me feel old! Here’s what’s happened to me since 2003: I got married. She was just my girlfriend in 2003.I met all three of my kids.I’ve had five different jobs, some were part-time summer jobs.I bought a house.I’ve gone to about 10 funerals for people I knew personally, including some close relatives.I got a dog. She’s watching me make this list and wondering if I’m going to walk her anytime soon.I picked up a bad coffee habit.I’ve bought three new cars.I’ve switched from PCs to Macs.I’ve become popular on Quora, which has been great for my self-esteem in the real world.You kids who are too young to remember 2003… you missed out.

I was 22 in 2003. Youth is really wasted on the young. Only if I knew what I knew now, I would have made some very different decisions. Hindsight is 20/20 vision. I discovered I had a lump in my left breast and had surgery to remove it for testing. It was benign - yeah!I quit my first job in Public RelationsI applied for University, deferred for a year - I really needed a recharge, went back to school and then successfully completed my degree.I started working at a bank after a short stint in a call centre - This was telling but I didn’t know it yetI tried to join the military as a reserve and failed (Being a cadet in school was not helpful, I should have worked on my fitness instead)I got promoted twice - Guess what? I became the Supervisor of the banks’ call centreI had my daughterI almost died - Pulmonary Embolism after a C-Section - If you’re not breathing properly something is wrong, don’t lie in bed hoping it will improve. Thanks for pushing me to go the Accident and Emergency Mom!I quit my job at the bank - 10 years! Whew! Time for a new adventure or is it torture?I dived into entrepreneurship - it’s so hard, but the small successes are worth it.And I discovered Quora. I just read at first and laughed a lot. Then I decided to add my two cents. I still have not figured out what its worth yet. Darn, just realized that two cents can only be worth two cents unless my coins are obscure, and not spendable.Wow a lot really has happened since 2003.

In 2003 I was ten, so: My cat Mimi had a few litters of kittens (now she's been gone for 2 years).I finished school, highschool and became an adult who attends college/University and works full time.I met a young man, he became my boyfriend a few days later, and 3 years after that we got married (this happened 7 years ago)So I moved to my first adult home - which has changed a lot aesthetically since then but it's the same apartment.I had my first an only baby (so far), so childbirth without epidural and raising a baby without epidural hahaRemoved a tooth (a frisky fang that got in the way)Climbed a small clay-soil cliff (about 5 meters)Painted my first canvas and many after thatDyed my hair for first and second timeDiscovered I really like to design scientific postersBought matching shirts and they're original Star Wars (yay!)Some of them are so uneventful that you'll get the idea of how cozy and homey I am.

It's changed completely. I am done with my Graduation in Clinical Psychology, which was like a dream. Also I completed my Post Graduation in Counselling Psychology. Mean while I did my internship at Children's hospital, at psychologist's clinic,Public hospital. Also, I developed feeling about men that they are not worth any of my love.And I will never find love in my life. Went to few places to explore with friends got drunk badly, smoked some pot and cigarettes but regretted it after doing it for 4 th time. Finally, thought of giving a try to a guy who shows up out of blue and who is extremely gorgeous and is a feminist. Who respects women and supports them. And I proved my friends wrong who thought I will never get married, I am the first one who got married. Yes I married him. And now I am working with school as school counselor. Since I love being around kids. All this year, I understood what truly I want or at least I tried to understand. My life has drastically changed in all these years. I was pretty messed up and disappointed during transition phase but now while writing this answer I feel glad about all the changes.

Since 2003 till 2014, I was very same, no changes in thoughts, actions and behavior. But in 2014, to those whom I was considering like a true friends have hurt me, and showed my their real face. Since then I have become very selective in choosing friends. Since then, one more thing I have learned that we should not indulge in fantasy of friendships. Everyone can not be your friend. We should learn to read the person. We should not give much importance to the person who does not deserve it by any means, in any manner. Do not allow anybody to take measurement of your height and size. Some people comes close to you to measure you, so that they can increase it to your size, with a intention to swallow you. Hence always keep such cunning person in their limits.

Oh, incredibly bad but also incredibly good.In 2004 I got married and had a kid in 2005. I'm still very hapily married (and I got another kid this year).So that's very good. But at the same time, when I got married and had a kid, this large change triggered panic anxiety syndrome (commonly happens when you make large changes in your life, for some people), which has been a pretty crippeling problem at times. That's very bad.But then again, before I got married (at age 23), I wasn't living a very nice or steady life, and I was very poor when I was young, but now I'm doing perfecctly fine.So overall... I don't know. I'd say it's clearly "better", but it depends on what apsect I look from.

I was six years old at the time, so I’d like to think of the past ~15yrs as the transition from dream to reality. Three big things I went from telling all my friends about how my dad was fortunate to attend Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, to attending there myself and beginning my career as an engineer.I’ve driven a few vehicles that 6 year old me would love to hear about; a 900cc Harley Davidson, a new GT Mustang, a 650bhp Foxbody set up for drag racing, and a couple Porsches.I am no longer afraid of life. I am free to do with it what I choose. I used to be afraid that I wouldn’t be successful.

At the beginning of 2003, I would have been about 13 months old. Since then, Both of my siblings were born.I started and finished preschool, elementary school, and junior high.I met most of my friends.Two of my grandparents and three of my great grandparents died.I’ve traveled to two countries and more than half of the US states.I’ve learned almost everything I know today.I learned to read, and put that knowledge to good use.And many more things. I will edit this answer to include more as I think of them.
I was fired from my last job that year. Since then, I have been physically unable to work, due to worsening physical disabilities. Believe me, being unable to work or leave the house is THE PITS!
Well, I was born in 2004. So…
